I am a UX/UI designer with front-end development experience. I previously worked as a Full Stack developer, although I was always more drawn to the front-end, especially UX/UI design. That's why I decided to specialize, and now I have several years of experience creating intuitive and attractive user experiences.

The naming of my professional brand is Toan. This choice is not arbitrary, but is based on a personal and emotional bond that directly reinforces my brand's philosophy: trust and accompaniment throughout the process. Toan is not a random invention, but a word with a deep and personal emotional charge. Its origin dates back to my childhood, when I had difficulty pronouncing the letter 'J' and referred to myself as "Toan" instead of "Joan". This small peculiarity became an affectionate nickname used by my closest loved ones, a symbol of unconditional support and acceptance.

Years later, this name acquired a new dimension when my partner started using "Toan" affectionately, without knowing the story from when I was a child. This coincidence confirmed its meaning for me: the name now symbolizes a path of constant support, trust, and fidelity.
In the professional context, Toan becomes the voice of my brand and the pillar of my value proposition:

When Someone needs to comply with digital accessibility in the digitalization process, Toan promises that the client will not have to face the legal and technical complexity alone, but will be guided by a close relationship and mutual support.
This orthographic singularity and its strong sonority help the brand stand out visually and be easily remembered in an environment often saturated with generic or overly formal names.

Toan is, therefore, more than a name; it is a declaration of trust, a commitment that profitable Accessibility will be delivered with the same care and support found in the most significant personal relationships.

My difference is my hybrid profile (UX/UI, front-end developer, and specialized digital accessibility profile) and my 360° product vision. When a client hires me, they are not just buying a graphic deliverable (the prototype), but the guarantee of an efficient end-to-end process (the solution). The added value I deliver is twofold:
My designs inherently include Frontend logic, as well as compliance with accessibility criteria, semantic naming, wai-aria tags, and QA checking from the design phase.

This integration drastically reduces iterations and errors between design and development teams, which translates into quantifiable savings in the total public project budget. Accessibility becomes a source of efficiency, not an expense.

Working on top-secret projects (aerospace and public administration) means much of my work is confidential. The challenge was how to demonstrate my UX, UI, Front-End, and Accessibility skills without showing embargoed screens. The solution couldn't be a simple theoretical mockup; it had to be a live and accessible product.

The market is often based on showing the "what" (the final result), but not the "how" (the process and ingenuity). My frustration was that I couldn't convey the technical depth behind each confidential solution. I needed a canvas to show not just a beautiful design, but functional, accessible, and bold code.
And how did I fix it?
I created this very portfolio portal as my most ambitious project: a functional example built from scratch that demonstrates my competencies at the highest level.
This portal complies with the WCAG Triple AAA accessibility level, in both light and dark modes. This is a strong statement of my priority for inclusive design.
The promise of the unique experience:

To demonstrate the power of my accessible color palette generator, every time the portal loads, a completely new primary color is generated, and from that, a unique accessible palette is built. This conveys that my approach to the end-user (and to you) will always be unique and exclusive.

I identify with the Japanese mindset: if someone has done it, I can also learn to do it; but if no one has done it, I must be the first to achieve it. This portfolio is my proof that I actively seek to overcome known boundaries.
Result and the fear of sharing:
Am I afraid to make the code for my tools public? The answer is a resounding No.

My goal is twofold: first, to show what I can do and how I face challenges. And second, to foster accessibility. If someone uses my code as a reference point, I feel proud. And if someone improves it, they'll be showing me that I still have much to learn.
This portfolio is a manifesto of humility and ambition: a solid foundation for creating superior and 100% accessible user experiences.

Everyone knows they must comply with WCAG standards, but the reality is that a single contrast error forces recalculating the entire palette (dark variants, light variants, hover states...) in a slow process full of potential manual errors. We needed a tool that would give us speed, consistency, and reliability in a demanding environment like aerospace and administration.

There are many contrast calculators on the market, but they all limit themselves to saying "Does not comply" or "Does comply." The problem was the effort the design and development teams had to invest after the error message.
The goal was not only to validate but to propose the solution at the same moment. We had to go further to eliminate the trial and error loop from our work.
And how did I fix it?
I decided to develop my own autonomous tool. This contrast check functions as an Integral Palette Assistant, and not just a simple calculator:
Shows the real contrast and allows selecting the required WCAG standard (A, AA, or AAA) with a simple level selector.
If the ratio fails, the tool automatically suggests the color most similar to the original that does comply with the requested standard.

From the corrected main color, the tool instantly generates the complete accessible palette (main color, contrast color, dark/light variants) and the minimum necessary variations for all components to be accessible on light and dark backgrounds.

Not only did we guarantee legal compliance and accessibility without room for error, but we saved hours of work, as the tool delivers a ready-to-code palette that the developer can implement directly.

Complex data tables are an eternal challenge in mobile design. The quick option is horizontal scroll, but this is not only a bad experience (UX) but often invalidates the WCAG 1.4.10 (Reflow) guideline, forcing the user to move in two dimensions. For administration projects, where data clarity is crucial, we need solutions that are 100% accessible and visually superior.

The main obstacle was maintaining the semantic context of each data point when the table transformed. In the mobile view, the user loses the column title reference, making the reading of complex data inefficient and frustrating.
In addition, most solutions rely on a Media Query based on the screen size, which is invalid when the table is in a narrow container, breaking the modularity of the design.
And how did I fix it?
I implemented an intelligent front-end solution, converting each table row into a vertical card in the mobile view. This solution is not only more visual but also guarantees data accessibility:
To each data cell, I added a data-label="" attribute containing the original column title. This ensures the semantic relationship is not lost and remains accessible to screen readers.

Instead of relying on the global viewport, I used Container Queries (@container). Thus, the table detects the actual width of its container (.responsive-table-wrapper) and only transforms when the space is reduced.

In the small view, each row transforms into a block (display: flex; flex-direction: column;). The column title is inserted as a pseudoelement (td::before) using the content of the data-label, offering a clear and linear reading experience.

I complied with the WCAG Reflow standard and provided a superior user experience, eliminating the need for lateral sliding. The implementation with Container Queries ensures this table is 100% modular and consistent in any layout context.

Working with multiple clients and products (especially in administration) means a constant struggle to maintain visual consistency and development efficiency. The great challenge is to create unique and distinctive designs for each branding without having to design and code every component from scratch. We needed a single CSS code base that could serve multiple products.

Before this solution, customizing a new portal required the direct intervention of a design team to change colors, spacing, and typography, generating duplicate CSS and a high risk of inconsistencies. Any modification or change in requirements (such as increasing the accessibility level) was costly and slow, as it had to be applied manually to each product file.
And how did I fix it?

I created a Modular Layout System based on CSS Variables (or Design Tokens). This system allows for the complete customization of a portal or application's appearance directly from the HTML, without touching the base CSS.

All main CSS (colors, spacing, text sizes, border-radius) was modularized using CSS variables. This means that the functionality (e.g., a button) is the same, but its visual style depends on a few lines of code.

Customization is done by adding a few classes to the <body> tag (e.g., <body class="contenedor-full font-serif radius-smooth font-combo-1">). These classes simply override the values of the global CSS variables, changing the appearance of the entire website.

This architecture ensures that, regardless of the selected token combination, the system always maintains the minimum accessibility levels required by public administration (contrasts, font sizes) by default.

I achieved extreme scalability. A developer or designer can select the layout, typography, rounding, and margins of a new portal in a matter of minutes. We went from designing to configuring, saving hours of design and development on every new project, with the added guarantee of consistent accessibility.
